_accidents.CI_OtherType: Removed compressors from service. Discontinued using equipment.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following summary is intended to meet the requirements of 40 CFR Subpart G § 68.155.  Pioneer Natural Resources' Risk Management Program is based on the API publication 761: Model Risk Management Plan guidance for Exploration and Production Facilities.

The accidental release prevention and emergence response policies at Fain Gas Plant are included in the facility's Emergency Response Manual and PSM program.  The Emergency Response Manual covers action to be taken in case of an unplanned release.  The mechanical intergrity section of PSM discusses action to be taken in order to prevent an unplanned accidental release of regulated substances.

The Fain Gas Plant consists of two natural gas processing plants operating in parallel.  Processes involved include:  gas conditioning through amine stripping, condensate stabilization, dehydration using TEG and molecular sieve technology, NGL extraction, Nitrogen rejection, and Helium recovery.  Gas condensate is transported via pipeline.  The natural gas liquids (NGL) are transported by pipeline from the facility.  The Helium recovered is compressed and transported via pipeline to market.  The remaining residue gas, mostly methane, is directed to pipeline for transport.

Fain Gas Plant was determined to be a program level 1 facility through the worst-case scenario analysis.  The worst-case scenario for this facility would be a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) due to the instantaneous release of a mixture containing 136,800 pounds of butane, 91,200 pounds of ethane, 4,560 pounds of methane, 41,040 pounds of pentane, and 136,800 puounds of propane of gas condensate from storage.  The radius of exposure (ROE) for this volume, assuming a fully loaded storage tank, is 0.6 miles.  There are no public or environmental receptors located in the radius of exposure.  The level in the storage tank is monitored frequently by the plant operators who man the facility 24 hours a day.  The tanks are also protected by pressure relief va

lves to prevent the possibility of over pressuring.

The general accidental release prevention measures taken are outlined in the mechanical integrity section of the PSM program for the facility.  Major components of this section that contribute to the prevention of accidental releases include:  testing of critical control and shutdown instruments, testing of pressure relief valves, and routine testing of piping and vessel corrosion.

On May 15, 2005, corrosion in an inlet vessel containing unprocessed gas and liquids caused a liquid spill, gas release, explosion, and fire.  The fire burned for approximately two hours, from 4:00 AM to 6:00 AM.  There was no off-site impact.  There were no fatalities, no injuries, no environmental impact except localized on-site soil contamination, and $4.3 million in equipment damage.  As a result of the incident, Fain Gas Plant improved equipment, revised maintenance, revised training, revised emergency response plan, revised operating procedures, implemented new process controls, created new mitigation systems, and changed the process.

The emergency response program for this facility is contained in the Emergency Response Manual, ERM.  A copy of the ERM has been provided to the Local Emergency Planning Committee of Potter/Randal County.  The ERM includes steps to take in case of an uncontrolled release of hazardous substance.  The initial step would be to contact the Potter/Randall County Emergency Response system which in turn will contact other emergency response agencies to aid in controlling access to the facility by the public.

The facility has ongoing programs that help train personnel in areas that have the greatest potential for uncontrolled release of hazardous substances.  In addition to utilizing PSM for hazard assessment, safety training is done in which items are discussed and resolved.

Summary for incident dated March 6, 2018

The following summary is intended to meet the requirements of 40 CFR Subpart

G § 68.155.  Pioneer Natural Resources' Risk Management Program is based on the API publication 761: Model Risk Management Plan guidance for Exploration and Production Facilities.

The accidental release prevention and emergence response policies at Fain Gas Plant are included in the facility's Emergency Response Manual and PSM program.  The Emergency Response Manual covers action to be taken in case of an unplanned release.  The mechanical intergrity section of PSM discusses action to be taken in order to prevent an unplanned accidental release of regulated substances.

The Fain Gas Plant consists of two natural gas processing plants operating in parallel.  Processes involved include:  gas conditioning through amine stripping, condensate stabilization, dehydration using TEG and molecular sieve technology, NGL extraction, Nitrogen rejection, and Helium recovery.  Gas condensate is transported via pipeline.  The natural gas liquids (NGL) are transported by pipeline from the facility.  The Helium recovered is compressed and transported via pipeline to market.  The remaining residue gas, mostly methane, is directed to pipeline for transport.

Fain Gas Plant was determined to be a program level 1 facility through the worst-case scenario analysis.  The worst-case scenario for this facility would be a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) due to the instantaneous release of a mixture containing 136,800 pounds of butane, 91,200 pounds of ethane, 4,560 pounds of methane, 41,040 pounds of pentane, and 136,800 puounds of propane of gas condensate from storage.  The radius of exposure (ROE) for this volume, assuming a fully loaded storage tank, is 0.6 miles.  There are no public or environmental receptors located in the radius of exposure.  The level in the storage tank is monitored frequently by the plant operators who man the facility 24 hours a day.  The tanks are also protected by pressure relief valves to prevent the possibility of over pressuring.

The general accidenta

l release prevention measures taken are outlined in the mechanical integrity section of the PSM program for the facility.  Major components of this section that contribute to the prevention of accidental releases include:  testing of critical control and shutdown instruments, testing of pressure relief valves, and routine testing of piping and vessel corrosion.

On March 6, 2018 due to undetermined causes, inlet compressor building GMV 1-6 experienced a fire on compressor #4. The fire started at approximately 9:30 pm and burned for about 6 hours, until fuel sources were eliminated and excess fuel was used up. There was no off-site impact.  No injuries or fatalities occurred, no impact to the environment.  Damage to equipment and facilities was estimated to be $9 million. As a result of this incident, this compressor building and related equipment was abandoned in place and removed from service.  Revisions were made in regards to emergency response procedures, training has been revised, and changed process for compressing inlet gas coming into facility.

The emergency action program for this facility may be found in the Emergency Action Plan, EAP. An updated copy of the EAP has been shared with the Local Emergency Planning Committee of Potter/Randall Counties.  Steps have been included to take in the event of an unplanned/uncontrolled release of hazardous materials.  The initial step would be to contact the Potter/Randall Emergency Response system which will begin the process of contacting other emergency response agencies.

The facility has ongoing programs that help train personnel in areas that have the greatest potential for uncontrolled release of hazardous substances.  In addition to utilizing PSM for hazard assessment, safety training is done in which items are discussed and resolved.
